awd_titl_txt: Optical Feshbach Resonances and Solitons in Quantum Degenerate Strontium
awd_abstract_narration:
Many technological marvels in modern society rely upon our ability to
understand and control the properties of materials on a microscopic
level, such as tuning the electrical conductivity in semiconductors that
are used to make computer chips. In the last decade, there have been
great advances in the creation and study of ultracold clouds of gaseous
atoms, which are cooled by lasers to temperatures around a millionth of
a degree above absolute zero. Ultracold atoms made in this way have the
amazing property that their interactions can be arbitrarily controlled,
which opens the possibility of using them to make designer materials or
test models of complex and important phenomena such as high temperature
superconductivity. The tool currently used to control these interactions
is the application of a strong magnetic field, but magnetic fields have
disadvantages; it is difficult to quickly change large magnetic fields
or vary fields on small length scales. Prof. Killian's research group at
Rice University in Houston, Texas will develop new techniques for
manipulating atom-atom interactions using lasers, which are much more
flexible and may open the way to new applications such as laser beams
made of atoms instead of light, or the ability to make new states of matter.

This work will also involve at least two graduate students and one
undergraduate student, and it will train them for high-technology
careers in optics or materials. The ultracold atomic physics laboratory
at Rice also has a partnership with the Houston campus of Yes Prep High
School, a highly successful charter school targeting disadvantaged
youth. This collaboration brings high school students into the
laboratory for term-time visits and summer camps, and introduces them to
the excitement of science at the frontiers of discovery in hopes of
inspiring them to pursue science, technology, engineering, and math
careers. Basic atomic physics experiments such as these are laying the
scientific and human resources foundation today for the technological
marvels of tomorrow.

por.por_cntn:
National Science Foundation-supported research at Rice
University studies the behavior of dilute gases at temperatures as low as 10
billionths of a degree above absolute zero. In this regime, quantum mechanics
dominates; more than one particle can be in exactly the same place at the same
time, and a single particle can be in more than one place at a time. When a
system of many particles enters this regime, the system is referred to as “quantum
degenerate.” The strange properties of such systems underlie important
macroscopic phenomena that are more familiar to us, like magnetism and superconductivity.
 In order to understand these phenomena,
and search for new effects, we create simple model systems that allow us to
isolate and probe the underlying physics. Ultracold atoms serve this important
role because the individual particles are well characterized, and their
interactions can be controlled in ways that are not possible with traditional
materials.

During the period of this grant, we created the first quantum
degenerate gases of atomic strontium, which opens new possibilities for
studying exotic material properties.  Strontium
in particular, has two valence electrons, which is unlike most other elements
that have been coaxed into the quantum degenerate regime. This difference has
been predicted to lead to new types of collective properties in quantum fluids.
In particular, it enables lasers to be used to control the interactions between
the atoms, through an “optical Feshbach resonance.” Interactions can be made negligible,
strongly attractive, or strongly repulsive, which is very valuable for studying
the fundamental properties of these systems and also holds promise for
applications such quantum computing.

The attached false-color images of strontium atoms
show, from left, a sample just before the transition to a quantum degenerate regime, in
which it forms a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC); the start of the BEC's
formation as the atoms chill to near absolute zero (the blue
"pedestal" at the bottom is atoms not yet in the condensate), and
right, a pure BEC. The BEC contains about 300,000 atoms and is about 50 mm in diameter. The BEC is narrow because
the atoms have entered a state that has the minimum kinetic energy possible,
and thus the BEC atoms do not move as far when the atoms are released from
their trap. Atoms in a BEC share a collective identity, similar to photons in a
laser beam. For example, it is possible to make holograms from interfering BECs
just like with interfering laser beams. The phenomenon of BEC is named after
Albert Einstein and Satyendra Nath Bose, who predicted such behavior in the
early 20th century.

10 graduate and undergraduate students also worked on this
project, contributing to the supply of people trained in technical fields. Students
learn how to plan and execute a complicated, technical project, and then
analyze and present their results. These analytic skills are valuable whatever
professional path they eventually follow. 
Students learn technical skills related optics, electronics, computer data
acquisitions and experimental control, and vacuum systems. They also have many
opportunities to improve their communication skills through presentations at
group meetings, department seminars, professional conferences, and writing of
journal articles and theses.
